articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
The main idea of CSS Container Queries is to register an element as a “container” and apply styles to other elements when the container element meets certain conditions. 
CSS Container Queries originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: CSS Container Queries

articles.author: Geoff Graham
articles.description:
A comprehensive guide covering nine types of lengths that CSS uses to size elements in terms of dimensions, space, time, and even sound.
CSS Length Units originally published on CSS-Tricks, which is part of the DigitalOcean family. You should get the newsletter.
articles.title: CSS Length Units

sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine — For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Job openings typically cast a very restrictive frame for candidates, with long lists of expectations and requirements. But what if this narrow focus can overlook the value of “V”-shaped designers who excel by crossing boundaries, connecting dots, and innovating beyond rigid boxes?
articles.title: T-Shaped vs. V-Shaped Designers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Whether you want to take your user research skills to the next level, get better at UX writing, or stay up-to-date on the latest design trends, a newsletter is the perfect opportunity to get the best of the best resources delivered straight to your inbox on a regular basis. In this post, we highlight some design newsletters that you might want to consider subscribing to.
articles.title: Useful Email Newsletters For Designers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Juan Diego Rodríguez)
articles.description: What are these CSS Container Style Queries, and why should you use them? Juan Diego Rodríguez delves deeply into style queries, and not at the syntax level, but at what exactly they are solving and what sort of use cases you would find yourselves reaching for them in your work if and when they gain browser support.
articles.title: What Are CSS Container Style Queries Good For?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: The 2-page login pattern is becoming pervasive. Here are the reasons behind this design choice and alternative solutions to create a more efficient and user-friendly authentication experience.
articles.title: 2-Page Login Pattern, And How To Fix It

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Kristian Mikhel)
articles.description: Kristian Mikhel covers various practical applications of scents in product experience, from immersive entertainment to healing spaces and medical appliances, and how designers can drive innovation across spheres and disciplines.
articles.title: The Scent Of UX: The Unrealized Potential Of Olfactory Design

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Salma Alam-Naylor)
articles.description: Do perfect Lighthouse scores mean the performance of your website is perfect? As it turns out, Lighthouse is influenced by a number of things that can be manipulated and bent to make sites seem more performant than they really are, as Salma Alam-Naylor demonstrates in several experiments.
articles.title: How To Hack Your Google Lighthouse Scores In 2024

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: The times for CSS have probably never been more exciting than today. In this quick read, we’ve got some useful CSS tips and techniques for you that you can apply to your work right away. Let’s dive deeper into self-modifying CSS variables, hanging punctuation, and more.
articles.title: Useful CSS Tips And Techniques

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Victor Yocco)
articles.description: There’s more to achieving good UX than research and design. We need to effectively communicate our ideas to gain buy-in from key stakeholders. Victor covers how UX practitioners can harness the power of persuasion and other tactics from the field of communication when presenting research findings and design concepts to key stakeholders.
articles.title: Presenting UX Research And Design To Stakeholders: The Power Of Persuasion

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Addy Osmani)
articles.description: The web is still a young platform, and we’re only now beginning to recognize what “success” looks like for large projects. In his recent Smashing book, [Success at Scale](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/printed-books/success-at-scale/), Addy Osmani presents practical case studies featuring the web’s most renowned companies and their efforts to make big changes to existing apps and sites. In this article, Addy shows some of the key insights he has learned.
articles.title: Scaling Success: Key Insights And Practical Takeaways

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Let’s kick off June with some fresh inspiration! Artists and designers from across the globe once again tickled their creativity to celebrate the beginning of the new month with a collection of beautiful and unique wallpaper calendars.
articles.title: Ice Cream Ahead (June 2024 Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Geoff Graham)
articles.description: What does it mean to learn the “basics”, or fundamentals, of front-end web development? Is starting with HTML and CSS still the best entry point to learn how to make websites and apps when we have a seemingly endless supply of frameworks? Geoff Graham thinks so and discusses why you might consider going “back to basics” to start or move forward in your career.
articles.title: In Praise Of The Basics

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Imagine finally resolving never-ending discussions about UI decisions for good. Here are some practical examples of decision trees for UI components and how to use them effectively. An upcoming part of [Smart Interface Design Patterns](https://smart-interface-design-patterns.com).
articles.title: Decision Trees For UI Components

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Atila Fassina)
articles.description: Application frameworks have built whole ecosystems on top of them. Let’s take a closer look at serverless platforms such as Netlify’s [Platform Primitives](https://www.netlify.com/platform/primitives) and explore how they can increase our productivity with a serverless fullstack experience.
articles.title: The Era Of Platform Primitives Is Finally Here

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Daniel Yuschick)
articles.description: After years of relying on checkbox hacks to create a “switch” control for forms that toggle between two states, HTML may be gaining a native way to go about it by adding a `switch` attribute to checkbox inputs. Daniel Yuschick walks us through a first impression of switch controls and discusses current and ongoing considerations that need to be explored further before it is ready for prime time.
articles.title: Switching It Up With HTML’s Latest Control

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: How can we get better at naming? This post is dedicated to naming conventions, tips, and real-world examples that help you name things in a robust and flexible way.
articles.title: Best Practices For Naming Design Tokens, Components And Variables

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Brecht De Ruyte)
articles.description: It’s easy to get lost in a sea of CSS frameworks and libraries, each promising easier styling and smoother layouts. Brecht De Ruyte demonstrates four CSS utility classes (plus a bonus) using techniques that allow them to be used practically anywhere you need a particular layout — be it Grid or Flexbox — with configurable options.
articles.title: Modern CSS Layouts: You Might Not Need A Framework For That

articles.author: Anant Chowdhary
articles.description: Distributed systems generally involve the storage and exchange of huge amounts of data. Not all data is created the same, and some of it can even expire – by design.  As the Buddha said, "All conditioned things are impermanent." In this article, we'll look at how the concept of
articles.title: How to Use Time To Live in Event-Driven Architecture in AWS

articles.author: Bala Priya C
articles.description: Python supports the for-else loop construct that is lesser known but super helpful. If you’ve programmed in Python, you may have used the for loop to iterate over items in iterables such as lists. But for some use cases, using the for loop in conjunction with the else clause can
articles.title: How Does Python's For-Else Loop Construct Work?

articles.author: Kolade Chris
articles.description: This is the second part of my PHP array handbook. You can find the first part here [/news/php-array-handbook/], where I cover array basics. In the first part, you learned about arrays, how to create arrays, array functions, and how to loop through arrays. This second part will teach you how
articles.title: PHP Arrays in Practice: How to Rebuild the Football Team Cards Project with PHP and MongoDB

articles.author: Samyak Jain
articles.description: In this tutorial, you will learn about Python decorators: what they are, how they work, and when to use them.  But before diving into decorators, it's helpful to understand two foundational concepts in Python: first-class functions and closures. First-Class Functions in Python First-class functions mean that functions in Python
articles.title: What are Decorators in Python? Explained with Code Examples

articles.author: Beau Carnes
articles.description: If you want to learn about the concepts around generative AI without getting bogged down with the technical details, we have a great course for you. We just published a course on the freeCodeCamp.org YouTube channel that is a non-technical intro to g...
articles.title: A Non-Technical Introduction to Generative AI

articles.author: Beau Carnes
articles.description: Open source LLMs can help you create intelligent apps without having to pay for each API call. We just published a course on the freeCodeCamp.org YouTube channel that will teach you how to use the open source models from Mistral AI to create intellig...
articles.title: Building Intelligent Apps with Mistral AI

articles.author: Kealan Parr
articles.description: The Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC) is different at every company. The version control system used, peer review process, code review process, design review process, how you do CI, automated testing, and manual testing – all vary greatly depending on where you work. How a company plans, writes, builds, reviews, deploys,
articles.title: What is Trunk Based Development? A Different Approach to the Software Development Lifecycle

articles.author: Fanny Nyayic
articles.description: A masonry layout is a grid-based design where items are arranged in a way that minimizes vertical gaps between them.  an example of a masonry layoutUnlike traditional grids with fixed row heights, masonry layouts adjust the positioning of items dynamically based on their content height, creating a visually appealing
articles.title: How to Create a Masonry Layout Using HTML and CSS

articles.author: Privacy Tipster
articles.description: These days, there are many different types of attacks that can jeopardize your digital security and privacy. So it’s a good idea to stay up-to-date with best practices to keep you safe online.  But it can be hard to understand exactly how to do this. So I built this
articles.title: How to Improve Your Digital Security and Privacy – Best Practices for Developers

articles.author: Shrijal Acharya
articles.description: In this article, I will show you how you can host your React/Next.js app or any static web app on Azure Static Web Apps.  I will be showing you both ways of doing it – through the GUI and with the CLI. I assume you already have built a
articles.title: How to Host Static Sites on Azure Static Web Apps for Free
